text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with basil ricotta and yoky that's
right when most people hear gnocchi they
think of a potato bass dough which is
more common but it's also much more
difficult to work with
and while perfectly executed they are
amazing they aren't even for
professionals that easy to perfectly
execute which is exactly why I love this
ricotta based version so much and not
only is it significantly easier it's
also incredibly delicious and maybe most
importantly a lot of fun to make so
let's go ahead an get started and we'll
begin with the star of the show
some ricotta cheese and of course since
this is the main ingredient we're going
to want to use something nice here and
as you can see from that telltale
pattern mine was made in a basket or I
guess they just could have taken regular
ricotta and press these marks into it
but I'm sure it's legit so we're going
to need to get our hands on some real
full fat ricotta cheese to which we need
to add a whole bunch of fresh basil and
prepping that's going to be the next
step so what we'll do is pull the leaves
off a bunch of basil and give those a
nice wash and some cold fresh water and
once we give those a good swishing
around and we're sure they're clean what
we're going to do is blanch these
briefly in some simmering water right
just for a few seconds to lock in that
green color so let's bring some water to
a simmer and we will toss in our handful
of picked and wash leaves and we will
give that a little dunk / stir with our
strainer and like I said we only need to
do this for a few seconds basically as
soon as those leaves turn into that
beautiful dark green color we will use
our strainer to fish those out and we'll
transfer those right back into a bowl
cold water to stop the cooking and
that's it as soon as that's been
accomplished we can fish that basil out
and then we'll squeeze that dry in or
out a towel at which point it's ready to
puree and add to our cheese and to
accomplish that all we're going to need
to do is blend that with a couple eggs
and by the way pay attention this is a
great example of how to waste time by
trying to save time see I didn't feel
like cleaning my large blender so
instead I decided to use this mini food
processor which I know is terrible but
that didn't stop me I added my blanched
basil and my two eggs and I started to
blend and I kept blending waiting for it
to turn into that beautiful green color
I was looking for which never happened
because as I already knew this thing
doesn't work that well so I stopped and
transferred it into the
should have been in in the first place
which ended up working much better
except now not only did I have to clean
the blender I was trying to avoid trying
to clean I also have to clean my crappy
little mini food processor which I
shouldn't used in the first place so
kids let that be a lesson to you never
try to save time but anyway once we
successfully blended that basil with
those eggs we'll go ahead and add that
to our Bowl or ACOTA
and continue with the rest of the
ingredients the first of which will be
some kosher salt we will also add a
little pinch of cayenne as custom
dictates as well as grate in a little
bit of real Parmesan cheese and when I
say little I mean by wait it's going to
look like a ton check out my Mount
fromage EO here but I'm only using like
an ounce and a half of cheese but anyway
we're going to grate in some
parmigiano-reggiano followed by the last
official ingredient some flour and not
too much
this type of naki supposed to be very
very light and delicate all right we
don't want something dense and gummy all
right you want dense and gummy gnocchi
make the regular kind and then once we
have our ingredients in the bowl we'll
give that a thorough mixing which by the
way I usually start with the spatula not
the whisk because if you start mixing
with the whisk this is what happens
everything gets stuck in the middle of
the whisk before it's all mixed so I
stopped and cleaned it off with a
spatula and continue mixing with that
before switching back to the whisk to
give it one last mix to make sure
everything was perfectly integrated plus
I really enjoyed cleaning that whisk off
so much the first time I figured hey
let's do that one more time but bottom
line using some kind of combination of
whisk and spatula we are going to mix
that thoroughly
at which point technically it's ready to
use but I don't recommend it what I
really think we should do here is clean
up this bowl a little bit and then we'll
cover that with plastic before we pop it
in the fridge for an hour - or until
it's thoroughly chilled and while this
is optional and if you have the wicked
munchies you can't cook your naki right
away I do think this mixture is easier
to work with when it's cold plus we give
that flour time to hydrate as well as
all those ingredients time to meld
together so I did pop mine in the fridge
for a couple hours at which point it
looked like this pretty much exactly the
same but colder and slightly firmer at
this point we are ready to form and boil
our
naki which is not easy unless you have
two teaspoons then it's super easy
because to form these all we need to do
is take a spoonful and we'll sort of
pass that back and forth between the two
spoons as you see me doing here to sort
of form a Nakia shape dumpling which we
will then carefully drop into some
simmering salted water and for the sake
of filming I'm just going to do a few
and by the way if you're wondering why
the water was already dirty
of course I tested a few ahead of time
to check the seasoning which by the way
is an official tip and you might be
thinking hey aren't you a professional
those look kind of jagged and ugly well
first of all no not really
and secondly it doesn't matter as you'll
see once these are done they look
perfect in fact it's actually these
little imperfections that make them
perfect so as we form these we're just
going to drop them straight into that
simmering water and we will wait for two
things to happen first they're going to
float to the surface okay that's the
first thing we're going to look for and
once they do flow to the surface what we
want to do is cook these for a couple
minutes or until they're not mushy
anymore until they slightly spring back
to the touch all right so I gave a
little test here and they still felt a
little mushy inside so I let them go for
a few more seconds and game another test
and like I said they should just barely
spring back to the touch at which point
we can remove those with our strainer to
a plate to cool and I say too cool
because I'm going to saute these in
butter but you don't have to let yours
cool just go ahead and toss them with a
sauce of your choice and start chowing
down but I don't think they're going to
be as good as how we're about to do them
and you'll notice as they cool they will
firm up quite a bit but anyway once we
have all our batter shaped and boiled
and cooled what I like to do is give
them a little saute and some melted
butter so what we'll do is we'll melt
some butter over medium heat and
hopefully a nonstick pan and how far we
go here is going to be up to you I tend
to like mine fairly well browned whereas
other people my wife Michele in
particular prefers them with just a
little touch of color which is mostly an
aesthetic but also textural thing so as
usual that kind of thing is going to be
up to you
you are the flow key of your gnocchi but
regardless of how long you do it I
really do think these benefit from a
little browning so I gave mine a couple
minutes per side until they were nice
and golden brown the witch
we go ahead and transfer those onto a
warm plate and we will garnish very
simply with a little bit of that melted
butter and I should mention just because
I'm serving these so simply doesn't mean
you have to these of course would work
with any sauce you'd serve with an yaki
or pasta but anyway this time I'm going
very simple with just a little bit of
that melted butter from the pan as well
as a little extra touch of that
parmigiano-reggiano and I'm really not a
big i-told-you-so guy but remember when
I said don't worry about those
imperfections in the surface that when
these were cooked they were going to
look great well I told you check it out
most reasonable people would say those
are beautiful okay so as long as these
are about the same size each getting
smooth perfectly shaped pieces is not a
big deal and then we will finish up with
the world's most perfect sprig of basil
and that's it our basil ricotta gnocchi
are done and as good as I think these
look what I think is really going to
impress you is the taste and texture I
mean of course basil and ricotta are
going to be delicious together everybody
knows that but the way those ingredients
are put together here and this
impossibly light tender package is just
incredible in fact the funny thing here
is that these have the texture of what
people make in traditional potato
gnocchi strive for okay something that's
very light and delicate and not
something that's dense and heavy and
that's exactly what you're going to get
using this ricotta gnocchi technique
which by the way reminds me if your
family's not in to tell you food just
call these dumplings which is exactly
what they are although having said that
if your family doesn't like a telling
food you might need to look for a new
family that is not a great sign but
anyway whether you call them dumplings
or gnocchi I really do hope you give
these a try soon so head over to food

mounts and more info as usual and as
always enjoy
